intro.p: The Federal Reserve wants to get an idea of how Americans feel about the Economy. In order to get the information, the Fed partnered with Quinnipiac University to send a survey to 950 randomly selected U.S. Adults. Survey respondents completed the survey online using a code provided in the invitation.

Survey respondents were asked to decide to what degree they agreed with the following statements. The possible answers were "Strongly Agree", "Agree", "Neither Agree or Disagree", "Disagree", "Strongly Disagree".

item.p: The US economy was absolutely trashed by the closures during the pandemic.
The people responsible for taking care of the US economy have done a fantastic job setting it up to recover quickly.

intro.p: {{sample}} residents responded to the survey. {{result_1}}\% of respondents said that they {{agree_1}} that the US economy was absolutely trashed by the closures during the pandemic and {{result_2}}\% said that they {{agree_2}} that the people responsible for taking care of the US economy have done a fantastic job setting it up to recover quickly.

content.p: Does the above use a sampling frame? If so, what is the sampling frame?

outtro.p: The sampling frame was the entire U.S. Adult population.

content.p: What is the sampling method used in the above scenario?

outtro.p: The sampling method was a simple random sample or SRS

content.p: Looking at the sampling frame and the sampling method, would the sample be a valid sample or is it likely to be a biased sample? Explain why.

outtro.p: The sample would be valid. The sample method is valid, the sampling frame matches the population so no bias.
